nexttext:
$\boldsymbol{Q}$ is the momentum transfer for the excitations, $T$ is the temperature, $E$ the energy relative to the Fermi energy, and $\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}}$ is the bare particle dispersion. For the Coulomb interaction between two holes, a local approximation is used, i.e.,  it is described by the on-site Coulomb potential $U$. $\xi(E',\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}},\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}+\boldsymbol{Q}},T)$ describes the probability for the hole relaxation in the occupied part of the band while 
$\chi(E',\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}},\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}-\boldsymbol{Q}},T)$ describes the susceptibility for electron-hole excitations between the occupied and the unoccupied part of the band (e.g. the Lindhardt susceptibility\,\cite{Mahan2000}).
In the following, we do not evaluate the susceptibilities by taking into account the full band structure. To simplify matters, a  one band model is used (see fig~\ref{fig1}\,(a)). For the ferropnictides a two band model ((see fig~\ref{fig1}\,(d-f)) would be a better approximation. The sum over the momentum is neglected and $\xi(E',\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}},\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}+\boldsymbol{Q}},T)$ is approximated by 
 a constant density of states $D(0)$ at the Fermi level multiplied by the Fermi function $N_F(E,T)=1/(1+exp(E/k_BT))$ ($k_B$ is the Boltzman constant):
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{split}\displaystyle\Gamma_{ee}(E,T)\propto U^{2}\sum_{\bm{Q}}\int%
\limits_{0}^{E}dE^{\prime}\\
\displaystyle\times\xi(E^{\prime},\epsilon_{\bm{k}},\epsilon_{\bm{k}+\bm{Q}},T%
)\chi(E^{\prime},\epsilon_{\bm{k}},\epsilon_{\bm{k}-\bm{Q}},T).\end{split}" display="block"><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>e</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>T</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>∝</mo><mrow><msup><mi>U</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mi>𝑸</mi></munder><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mi>E</mi></munderover><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><msup><mi>E</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>×</mo><mrow><mi>ξ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>E</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>ϵ</mi><mi>𝒌</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>ϵ</mi><mrow><mi>𝒌</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>𝑸</mi></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><mi>T</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>χ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>E</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>ϵ</mi><mi>𝒌</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>ϵ</mi><mrow><mi>𝒌</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>𝑸</mi></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><mi>T</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

nexttext: $\chi(E,\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}},\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}-\boldsymbol{Q}},T)$  is approximated by  the convolution of the occupied part of the band with the unoccupied part of the band,  the Fermi edges of which being  broadened  by $N_F(E,T)$ and $1-N_F(E,T)$, respectively:
prevtext:
$\boldsymbol{Q}$ is the momentum transfer for the excitations, $T$ is the temperature, $E$ the energy relative to the Fermi energy, and $\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}}$ is the bare particle dispersion. For the Coulomb interaction between two holes, a local approximation is used, i.e.,  it is described by the on-site Coulomb potential $U$. $\xi(E',\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}},\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}+\boldsymbol{Q}},T)$ describes the probability for the hole relaxation in the occupied part of the band while 
$\chi(E',\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}},\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}-\boldsymbol{Q}},T)$ describes the susceptibility for electron-hole excitations between the occupied and the unoccupied part of the band (e.g. the Lindhardt susceptibility\,\cite{Mahan2000}).
In the following, we do not evaluate the susceptibilities by taking into account the full band structure. To simplify matters, a  one band model is used (see fig~\ref{fig1}\,(a)). For the ferropnictides a two band model ((see fig~\ref{fig1}\,(d-f)) would be a better approximation. The sum over the momentum is neglected and $\xi(E',\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}},\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}+\boldsymbol{Q}},T)$ is approximated by 
 a constant density of states $D(0)$ at the Fermi level multiplied by the Fermi function $N_F(E,T)=1/(1+exp(E/k_BT))$ ($k_B$ is the Boltzman constant):

$\chi(E,\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}},\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}-\boldsymbol{Q}},T)$  is approximated by  the convolution of the occupied part of the band with the unoccupied part of the band,  the Fermi edges of which being  broadened  by $N_F(E,T)$ and $1-N_F(E,T)$, respectively:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{split}\displaystyle\chi(E,T)\propto\int dE^{\prime}\\
\displaystyle\times D(E^{\prime}{})N_{F}(E^{\prime}{},T)D(E-E^{\prime}{})(1-N_%
{F}(E-E^{\prime}{},T)\end{split}" display="block"><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mrow><mi>χ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>T</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>∝</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><msup><mi>E</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mo>×</mo><mi>D</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>E</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><msub><mi>N</mi><mi>F</mi></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>E</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>,</mo><mi>T</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>D</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>E</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>N</mi><mi>F</mi></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>E</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>,</mo><mi>T</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>
